[[Image:Paterson strike leaders.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Strike leaders [[Patrick Quinlan (activist)|Patrick Quinlan]], [[Carlo Tresca]], [[Elizabeth Gurley Flynn]], [[Adolph Lessig]], and [[Bill Haywood]]]]
[[Image:Paterson strike leaders.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Strike leaders [[Patrick Quinlan (activist)|Patrick Quinlan]], [[Carlo Tresca]], [[Elizabeth Gurley Flynn]], [[Adolph Lessig]], and [[Bill Haywood]]]]
The '''Paterson silk strike of 1913''' was a strike of the silk mill workers in [[Paterson, New Jersey|Paterson]], [[New Jersey]]. Led by the [[Industrial Workers of the World]] (IWW), the strike began on [[February 1]], [[1913]]. The strikers demanded eight-hour work days and improved working conditions.<ref name=gompers-papers>The Samuel Gompers Papers.</ref> During the course of the strike, approximately 1,850 strikers were arrested, including IWW leaders [[Bill Haywood]] and [[Elizabeth Gurley Flynn]].<ref name=gompers-papers /> Despite the long holdout and fundraising efforts, the strike ended in failure on [[July 28]], [[1913]].
The '''Paterson silk strike of 1913''' was a strike of the silk mill workers in [[Paterson, New Jersey|Paterson]], [[New Jersey]]. Led by the [[Industrial Workers of the World]] (IWW), the strike began on [[February 1]], [[1913]]. The strikers demanded eight-hour work days and improved working conditions.<ref name=gompers-papers>The Samuel Gompers Papers.</ref> During the course of the strike, approximately 1,850 strikers were arrested, including IWW leaders [[Bill Haywood]] and [[Elizabeth Gurley Flynn]].<ref name=gompers-papers /> Despite the long holdout and fundraising efforts, the strike ended in failure on [[July 28]], [[1913]].
